title: 107_s2187
content: The Act titled "Department of Veterans Affairs Emergency Medical Care Act of 2002" authorizes the Department to provide health care during major disasters and medical emergencies. The Department of Veterans Affairs Emergency Medical Care Act of 2002 allows the Secretary to provide hospital care and medical services during major disasters and medical emergencies, as defined by specific criteria. The Department of Veterans Affairs Emergency Medical Care Act of 2002 authorizes the Secretary to provide care and services to veterans during disasters or emergencies, regardless of their enrollment status. Priority is given to veterans with service-connected disabilities and active-duty members of the Armed Forces receiving health-care services. The Department of Veterans Affairs Emergency Medical Care Act of 2002 allows the Secretary to provide care and services to veterans during disasters or emergencies, excluding those with service-connected disabilities and active-duty members receiving health-care services. Reimbursement for care provided to non-Department officers or employees is based on agreed-upon rates. Amounts received are credited to the facility that provided the care. In case of a disaster or emergency, care must be furnished within 60 days. The Secretary shall submit a report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs regarding the allocation of facilities and personnel for providing care during disasters or emergencies. Regulations will be prescribed for the exercise of the Secretary's authority under this section. During major disasters and medical emergencies, the Secretary may provide care and services without charges for emergency care. Members of the Armed Forces can receive hospital care, nursing home care, and medical services during periods of war, national emergencies, or disasters. During disasters or emergencies, the Secretary can provide hospital care and medical services to active duty Armed Forces members. This includes major disasters declared by the President or when the National Disaster Medical System is activated. The Secretary may prioritize care under this section over other types of care. During disasters or emergencies, the Secretary can provide hospital care and medical services to active duty Armed Forces members. The Secretary may prioritize care under this section over other types of care, except for veterans with service-connected disabilities. The terms 'hospital care', 'nursing home care', and 'medical services' are defined in specific sections of the title.
